docs.snippet: VOLKMAR--Isaac. The path we walked yearns your shadow. . . engulfed in your memory and wrapped in love a new day begins. For us a day without beginning, without end, just a continuation. . . we feel you. . . we love you. For children with a promis...
docs.lead_paragraph:
VOLKMAR--Isaac.

The path we walked yearns your shadow. . . engulfed in your memory and wrapped in love a new day begins. For us a day without beginning, without end, just a continuation. . . we feel you. . . we love you. For children with a promise inside, a day is brightened with your light of love and hope. And the pain becomes the truth and the truth becomes the light and the light becomes redeeming. Sweetie boy, I know your soul has always been blessed. . . for us and for many you are a blessing, an angel and pure love. We miss you and love you. Dad (pops)

docs.snippet: McCORMICK--Edward J., of Remsenburg, NY, formerly of New York City, died on January 11, 2016. He was 80 years old. He was a graduate of St. Peter's University and New York University School of Law. He is survived by his wife Mary, his four childre...
docs.lead_paragraph:
McCORMICK--Edward J.,

of Remsenburg, NY, formerly of New York City, died on January 11, 2016. He was 80 years old. He was a graduate of St. Peter's University and New York University School of Law. He is survived by his wife Mary, his four children, and eight grandchildren. Funeral Mass January 15th, 11am, Immaculate Conception Church, Westhampton Beach, NY.

docs.snippet: PRESENT--Daniel H., M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, Dr. Present combined an active clinical practice with prolif...
docs.lead_paragraph:
PRESENT--Daniel H., M.D.

The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of a beloved colleague, mentor, and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, Dr. Present combined an active clinical practice with prolific ground-breaking research in Gastroenterology. In the tradition of Drs. Crohn, Ginsberg, and Oppenheimer, he continued Mount Sinai's pioneering work in the study of inflammatory bowel diseases. Through his investigations, an important class of medications was added in treating Colitis and Crohn's Disease. He was awarded the prestigious Jacobi Medallion in 1991 and was a great supporter of the institution. A long term AAS board member, he served as President of the physicians' organization from 1979-1980. Dr. Present will be remembered for his outstanding contributions to the School and Hospital, and his commitment to excellence. His legacy will continue in the generations of students he taught and the many lives he touched. We extend condolences to his wife Jane and his entire family. Eric Neibart, M.D., President Mark Reiner, M.D., Vice President Amy Weinstein, Administrator

docs.snippet: SCHALLER--Ralph F., died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of January 10, 2016, next to his adored and adoring wife, Roni Schaller, who remained by his side throughout his illness. His friends and family cannot imagine life without him. A mem...
docs.lead_paragraph:
SCHALLER--Ralph F.,

died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of January 10, 2016, next to his adored and adoring wife, Roni Schaller, who remained by his side throughout his illness. His friends and family cannot imagine life without him. A memorial to celebrate his life will take place on Sunday, January 17, at 1:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. As Ralph told all who asked, "I had a great life, better than most."

died on January 2, 2016 in Paris, France. He is mourned by his wife, Caroline de Messieres, his daughters, Rachel Marschang and Shanti Knock, their mother, Patricia Knock, and his grandsons Abrahim, Ian and Jad.

docs.snippet: STEINBERG--Ethel Bookhalter, 97, on January 12, 2016. Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba and died in New York City. An independent woman ahead of her time, she was a Captain in the Canadian Army, and then a pediatrician serving the children of the New Yor...
docs.lead_paragraph:
STEINBERG--Ethel

Bookhalter, 97, on January 12, 2016. Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba and died in New York City. An independent woman ahead of her time, she was a Captain in the Canadian Army, and then a pediatrician serving the children of the New York City area. She shared her love of reading with her family and then as a volunteer with the New York City Public Schools. Survived by Herman, her devoted husband of 65 years, daughters Susan, Judith (Howard), Leslie, and Joan, grandchildren Aaron (Jillanne), Anne, David, Paul (Naeha), Rachel (Christopher), and Nathan, and great-grandchildren Thomas and Leena. All who knew her will remember her for her vitality. Gifts may be made in her memory to the New York Public Library. Service on Thursday, January 14 at 1pm at Star of David Funeral Home, 1240 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY. For more information: jewish-funeral-home.com.

docs.snippet: PRESENT--Daniel H., M.D. We at the Mount Sinai Health System are saddened by the passing of Daniel H. Present, M.D., a beloved physician who, in a five-decade career at Mount Sinai, was at the forefront of research into the diagnosis and treatment...
docs.lead_paragraph:
PRESENT--Daniel H., M.D.

We at the Mount Sinai Health System are saddened by the passing of Daniel H. Present, M.D., a beloved physician who, in a five-decade career at Mount Sinai, was at the forefront of research into the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). Dr. Present was the first researcher to show the effectiveness of an immunosuppressant, 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), in fighting Crohn's disease. When Dr. Present published his results in The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) in 1980, it changed the lives of thousands of Crohn's patients. Later, he studied the use of cyclosporine for severe steroid- refractory ulcerative colitis, and demonstrated that it could help avoid or delay colectomies in many of these seriously ill patients. In a third breakthrough in the late 1990s, Dr. Present studied cA2, also known as infliximab, an anti-tumor necrosis factor antibody, and showed, in another seminal paper in the NEJM, that it could help close fistulas in Crohn's patients. Early in his career at Mount Sinai, he was mentored by Henry D. Janowitz, M.D., for whom the Division of Gastroenterology is named. Dr. Present was also a talented clinician who cared for thousands of patients over his career. Over a decade ago, he and his wife, Jane, established an endowed fellowship at Mount Sinai to train graduates from outside institutions to become experts in the care of patients with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Dr. and Mrs. Present also maintained a foundation for clinical research of IBD. Upon his retirement from Mount Sinai in 2014, the foundation donated its principal in support of The Susan and Leonard Feinstein Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinical Center at Mount Sinai. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jane and their children, Douglas, Stephanie, and Tracy, at this difficult time. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, M.D. Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System
